q: What are the symptoms of an overactive thyroid?
a: Symptoms of an overactive thyroid include nervousness, anxiety, irritability, mood swings, difficulty sleeping, persistent tiredness and weakness, sensitivity to heat, swelling in the neck, irregular and/or fast heart rate, twitching or trembling, and weight loss.

q: When should I see a GP for symptoms of an overactive thyroid?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of an overactive thyroid. They will ask about your symptoms and may arrange a blood test to check how well your thyroid is working. Further tests may be done to identify the cause if the blood test shows an overactive thyroid.

q: What are the treatments for an overactive thyroid?
a: The main treatments for an overactive thyroid are medication to reduce hormone production, radioiodine treatment to destroy thyroid cells, or surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid. Each treatment has its own benefits and drawbacks, so discussing with a specialist is recommended.

q: What are the causes of an overactive thyroid?
a: Some causes of an overactive thyroid are Graves' disease, where the immune system produces antibodies that stimulate excessive hormone production, thyroid nodules that produce excess hormone, and certain medications like amiodarone.

q: What problems can an untreated or poorly controlled overactive thyroid lead to?
a: Untreated or poorly controlled overactive thyroid can lead to eye problems, pregnancy complications such as pre-eclampsia and premature birth, as well as a thyroid storm, which is a sudden and life-threatening flare-up of symptoms.

q: Where can I find help and support if I have an overactive thyroid?
a: The British Thyroid Foundation provides help and support for individuals with an overactive thyroid.

q: How does an overactive thyroid affect women compared to men?
a: An overactive thyroid is about 10 times more common in women than men.

q: At what age does an overactive thyroid typically occur?
a: An overactive thyroid typically occurs between 20 and 40 years of age.

q: What is the thyroid gland responsible for?
a: The thyroid gland produces hormones that affect things such as heart rate and body temperature.

q: What is Graves' disease?
a: Graves' disease is an autoimmune condition where the immune system produces antibodies that cause the thyroid to produce excessive thyroid hormones.

q: What is an overactive thyroid?
a: An overactive thyroid, also known as hyperthyroidism or thyrotoxicosis, is a condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormones.

q: What are the symptoms of an overactive thyroid?
a: Symptoms of an overactive thyroid include nervousness, anxiety, irritability, mood swings, difficulty sleeping, persistent tiredness and weakness, sensitivity to heat, swelling in the neck, an irregular and/or fast heart rate, twitching or trembling, and weight loss.

q: When should I see a GP for an overactive thyroid?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of an overactive thyroid. They can ask about your symptoms and arrange for a blood test to check how well your thyroid is working.

q: How is an overactive thyroid diagnosed?
a: An overactive thyroid is diagnosed through a blood test that checks the levels of thyroid hormones. Further tests may be done to identify the cause of the overactivity.

q: What are the treatments for an overactive thyroid?
a: The main treatments for an overactive thyroid are medication to regulate thyroid hormones, radioiodine treatment to reduce thyroid hormone production, or surgery to remove part or all of the thyroid.

q: What are the causes of an overactive thyroid?
a: The causes of an overactive thyroid include Graves' disease, nodules on the thyroid, and certain medications such as amiodarone.

q: What problems can an untreated or poorly controlled overactive thyroid lead to?
a: An untreated or poorly controlled overactive thyroid can lead to eye problems, pregnancy complications, and a life-threatening condition called a thyroid storm.

q: Where can I find help and support for an overactive thyroid?
a: You can find help and support for an overactive thyroid from the British Thyroid Foundation.

q: Who is more likely to have an overactive thyroid?
a: An overactive thyroid is about 10 times more common in women than men and typically occurs between the ages of 20 and 40.

q: What is the thyroid and what does it do?
a: The thyroid is a small butterfly-shaped gland in the neck that produces hormones affecting heart rate and body temperature.
